{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3503150,"name":"James","username":"JamerGamer789","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19b73/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T18:37:04.945Z","cooked":"

Our team has the Adafruit 5mm break beam sensor and the REV Data Port Breakout Board. I’ve seen some threads on CD about connecting it, but I’m still confused. How do I solder the break beam sensor to the SparkMAX board properly?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T18:37:04.945Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":77,"reads":192,"readers_count":191,"score":423.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":485316,"topic_slug":"wiring-break-beam-sensor-to-sparkmax","display_username":"James","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51278,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wiring-break-beam-sensor-to-sparkmax/485316/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3503155,"name":"Domtech","username":"Domtech","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/domtech/{size}/138487_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T18:41:24.105Z","cooked":"

The emitter gets soldered to 5V and Ground, and the sensor gets wired to 5V, Ground, and one of the limit pins.

Edit: You should also add a pull up resistor between the sense line and 5V or 3.3V (10K ohm, but anything between 5k and 40k should work).

Domtech:

Edit: You should also add a pull up resistor between the sense line and 5V (10K ohm, but anything between 5k and 40k should work).

That is so much extra work lol /s

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T19:05:15.098Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":28.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":485316,"topic_slug":"wiring-break-beam-sensor-to-sparkmax","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51278,"username":"JamerGamer789","name":"James","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/e19b73/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wiring-break-beam-sensor-to-sparkmax/485316/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3503201,"name":"Phalanx","username":"Phalanx","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/phalanx/{size}/1645_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T19:16:09.793Z","cooked":"

We attempted this last season with a different but similar IR sensor.
I wired +5, G, and then to one of the limit switch pins using the REV Breakout for the Sparkmax. We didn’t have that extra pull up resistor as suggested in this post.

After about an hour, the Sparkmax failed. I was doing post mortem with REV on it, but didn’t finish the process due to personal issues that arose after the season last year. FWIW.

Since the Spark Max supports both NO and NC does that imply that it has its own appropriate resistors so neither condition is subject to a random floating value? Also, the documentation says it’s easy to connect. Some may think wiring resistors is

TFM110:

so much extra work

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T19:34:06.723Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":120,"readers_count":119,"score":29.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":485316,"topic_slug":"wiring-break-beam-sensor-to-sparkmax","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":5123,"username":"Phalanx","name":"Phalanx","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/phalanx/{size}/1645_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/wiring-break-beam-sensor-to-sparkmax/485316/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3503281,"name":"Domtech","username":"Domtech","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/domtech/{size}/138487_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T19:56:04.147Z","cooked":"

We used several break beam sensors with SparkMaxes last year using these same breakout boards. We found that without the resistor the voltage on the sense wire “floats” very close to the cutoff where the SparkMax switches from reading High to Low. The pull-up resister brings the floating voltage up to 5v (or 3.3V) to make it very clearly above the cutoff when the photo-diode is not pulling the voltage to ground

I believe that it does have internal pull up resistors so you don’t have a floating random value. Better to ask REV directly to be certain. They are very responsive to questions and support.

docs.revrobotics.com

Data Port | REV ION Brushless

While I’ve never connected one via a SparkMax, we have connected other sensors to SparkMax and used Beam-breaks connected to the RIO.

Our workaround for avoiding pull-up resistors on beam-breaks is if the device isn’t working as a switch, just wire it via the analog input and have your programmers set a threshold to have it trigger like a switch.

The main reason you would need a pull-up resistor is if the output range of the sensor doesn’t match the expected trigger range of the switch inputs, but wiring it as an analog sensor bypasses that and lets you read the output voltage from the sensor directly.

I see that Phalanx already linked the page, but wording direct from there is:

SPARK MAX has two limit switch inputs that, when triggered, can independently prevent motion in both the forward and reverse directions. By default, when the pin for the corresponding direction is grounded, SPARK MAX will override any input commands for that direction and force the output into the neutral state. Input commands for the opposite direction will still be processed unless the corresponding limit signal is also triggered.

In order for this to work, there needs to be something that is exciting the pin – applying voltage to it – but will allow that voltage to be changed when the pin is forcefully connected to ground by the switch. It could be a pull-up resistor or a current-limiting source, but there has to be something.

An NPN-type open-collector output from a sensor either grounds the input pin, or goes high-impedance. The name comes from the idea of using an NPN transistor as a switch. In other words, it behaves very similarly to a switch connected between input pin and ground, where that switch is controlled by the sensor state.

The main reason you’d add an external pull-up resistor is if the sensor’s output circuitry has too much leakage, and is pulling down (voltage near ground/sinking current) when it shouldn’t be – either all the time, or intermittently (e.g., when the sensor is warm).

If you hook it up and it operates correctly, or it’s always high-impedance (pin voltage is always high logic level), adding a pull-up resistor won’t help. For example, if you have a PNP-type open-collector sensor, that’ll require a pull-down resistor instead.

You don’t need a resistor

Hello Tauseef,

Thank you for reaching out to REV Robotics!

Below is a recommended wiring sketch for using an IR Break Beam sensor with the SPARK MAX’s Data Port Breakout Board:

Screenshot_20250206_161654_Gmail1318×1976 324 KB

As an additional note: the SPARK MAX has internal pull-ups on the limit switch pins, so you shouldn’t need to add any external pull-up resistors to the circuitry.

That’s perfect! Thank you for reaching out. It might just be me but to clarify, the yellow signal can go to either F or R on the limit switch connectors, right?

Correct.

If you wanna be fancy you could even connect the signal to both F and R, and control which limit is enabled via the API. We did this last year.

One thing I’ll note is that I haven’t had a good experience powering the transmitting side of the beam break via the Spark Max itself. I’ve always powered it using a separate 5V source, like the VRM or MitoCANdria. The receiving side (the one with the signal pin) is fine being powered by the Spark Max.
